greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: If n = Product(pj^ej), i.e., written in its prime factorization, then a(n) = max_j{(pj-1)*ej}.
comment: The highest power of k dividing n! (A090622) is close to, but below, n/a(k).
link: David W. Wilson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..10000
A. M. Oller-Marcen, J. Maria Grau, On the Base-b Expansion of the Number of Trailing Zeros of b^k!, J. Int. Seq. 14 (2011) 11.6.8, propos. 3.
formula: a(b*c) = max(a(b), a(c)) for b and c coprime.
a(n) = lim_{k->inf} k/A090622(k, n) = lim_{k->inf} (k/highest power of k dividing n!). - _David W. Wilson_, Sep 05 2016
mathematica: a[n_] := Module[{aux = FactorInteger[n]},Max[Table[aux[[i, 2]]*(aux[[i, 1]] - 1), {i, 1, Length[aux]}]]] (* _José María Grau Ribas_, Feb 15 2010 *)
program: (PARI) a(n)=my(f=factor(n)); vecmax(vector(#f~,i,(f[i,1]-1)*f[i,2])) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 07 2016
results.author: _Henry Bottomley_, Dec 06 2003
